Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-Australia IRES Collaboration: Behavioral ecology research training in Australia's tropical savannah
Award.AbstractNarration:
This International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) award is made to Professor Jordan Karubian in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Tulane University in New Orleans, Louisiana. The 21 participating U.S. graduate and undergraduate students will collaborate for two months over a period of three years with researchers in the School for Environmental Research at Charles Darwin University in Australia. Their foreign collaborators at the Institute are Professor Michael Lawes and Professor Donald Franklin. The students will study avian behavioral ecology and fire ecology research in the world?s largest remaining tropical savannah habitat. The research will develop an understanding of the relationship between the environment, demography, and the mating system of the red-backed fairy-wren. The students will exploit the considerable flexibility these wrens exhibit in social organization, expression of sexual signals, and mating behavior in an area in which ecological conditions vary in a patchwork manner. By characterizing the degree to which the wrens use flexible behavioral and physiological strategies to negotiate the ecological and social environment that they experience, and comparing this reproductive flexibility with other tropical and temperate species, it is likely that this research will further our understanding of avian mating systems and how they respond to anthropogenic activities. The program will provide technical training in cutting edge behavioral ecology methods and will build the capacity of these students to work with foreign collaborators in the future. The researchers also plan to include Australian Aboriginal groups in their field research projects.

A major emphasis of the project is to engage U.S. students in meaningful projects with international students and faculty. Students will work closely with researchers with different scientific backgrounds and will learn field and laboratory techniques that will enhance their research skills. Altogether, these experiences will increase the networking and international competitiveness of the student participants. The research program will have broad impacts on biological education and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This IRES award provided international training in STEM for biology students at Tulane, Cornell, and William & Mary. The award supported 21 IRES fellows (18 undergraduates and 3 graduate students), with strong representation by traditionally under-represented groups (out of the 18 undergraduate students: 12 females; 2 Hispanic; 1 African-American; 1 Native American; and 1 first-generation university student). Each fellow participated in a year-long training experience that included: (a) a one-credit semester-long pre-departure seminar with regular webinars including all participants; (b) an 8-9 week international research experience in Northern Territory, Australia; and (c) a three-credit semester-long post-travel course in which data were analyzed and prepared for dissemination, with regular webinars and interchange.

 

Intellectual Merit: Student research projects focused on the impacts of fire on social behavior of the red-backed fairy-wren Malurus melanocephalus, a small passerine bird, during the non-breeding season. With PI guidance, students independently developed hypotheses, yielding a suite of complementary and cohesive studies spanning the award period. Students found that low to moderate intensity fires were associated with: (a) changes in vegetative structure and insect abundances; (b) increased densities, alterations of anti-predatory vigilance behaviors, larger flock sizes, and higher rates of social interactions among red-backed fairy-wrens; and (c) changes in habitat use, with a shift toward unburnt areas but no detectable impact on survival or physiological condition. Moreover, fires changed the acoustic landscape for these birds. Taken as a whole, these studies suggest that low to moderate intensity fires may benefit red-backed fairy-wrens in the short-term, though important questions remain about the longer-term impacts.

 

Broader Impacts: This project has resulted in four student-led publications (in Auk, Zoo Biology, and the peer-reviewed Tulane Undergraduate Research Journal), with an additional four papers in review or close to submission. Nine IRES participants have made poster presentations at national scientific meetings to date. One IRES fellow was awarded ‘Best Student Poster’ at the 2014 Wilson Ornithological Society meeting, and a second IRES fellow was a Runner-Up at the 2014 Animal Behavior Society meeting. Three students completed honors theses, and a fourth received the ‘Phi Beta Phi Award’ for Best Undergraduate Paper by an Ecology & Evolutionary Biology or Earth & Environmental Science student. Students received prestigious fellowships from NSF GRFP and EPA. In addition to research per se, students also interacted with Australian hosts and practicing scientists, visited multiple natural areas (including Kakadu National Park) each year, and were exposed to a broad range of cultural experiences. The project website (http://redbackedwren.wordpress.com - 19,600 page views to date) features reports, honors theses, informal blogs and posts. Short (3-5 min), student-produced videos about their IRES experience are available on the project website and Cornell’s popular ‘All About Birds’ website (http://blog.allaboutbirds.org/2014/08/13/seven-ways-of-looking-at-a-fairywren-student-research-in-australia/).
